data.text: Size of Rear Panniers for Basics Camping Equipment?
Hi all, newbie question here. How large should rear panniers be to contain standard camping gear eg tent, bag, mat, clothes etc. I'm having trouble dealing with litres in my head. Many thanks

Different t foreverybody. It really depends on how much you plan to take and the climate. For eg I think mine are 20 litres and I can get all I need for 2 weeks camping minus food which I buy daily. but if you're going off the beaten track you need extra for food water.

data.text: Do you have a rucsac with a known capacity, perhaps a medium day pack? If so, get all your stuff together that you think you will take. Then put aside anything that's a maybe. (because you probably shouldn't be taking it - cut down spare clothes and footwear especially). Pack the rest.. see how many of those daysac's your gear fills. Then you'll know. But if I had to pick, for someone starting up, I'd guess 20L each side is about right. That's pretty standard for rear panniers. Tent can go separate, strapped on top of the rack, so you don't have to include that. Maybe plus a handlebar bag, say 6L.

data.text: The most obvious answer would be: get the biggest panniers you can get. It's better to have packed all the gear and still have room left versus having no room left and still gear to pack. But, getting the biggest panniers requires a significant trade: discipline. I see a lot of people stuffing those last free spaces just so the pannier is full. That's ridiculous of course. I always recommend beginners to stuff their panniers with every useful, less useful, and useless item they can find. Then set off on a 1-day tour (better, an overnighter), add in some decent climbs and descents. When they come back, they already have a rough idea of which items are labeled "useless" and which ones are "less useful" and "useful". Of the "less useful" one has to decide if it is worth the effort of bringing along or not.

data.text: As I ride a recumbent and there are few choices for a decent sized pannier , I made my own . I based the size on existing camping equipment, not on what is available on the market now. My 2"thermorest pad is 5.5 " in diameter by 22" long and it fits the inside bottom of my pannier. If I wanted to spend 300+ bucks I could get a new Thermorest that is better insulating , smaller compact roll ,that takes up half the room. Everything I take is inside my panniers and protected from rain without an optional cover. As someone pointed out the last thing you want is a wet tent next to your sleeping bag . Simple cure is a drybag for your tent. So for the person who wants to know how much fits where, you need to take what you think you need to the store and stuff it into the display pannier to get a sense of carrying capacity. Bigger is better as you do not have to carry as much as it holds and later on , after your tour ,you may just need that room for a grocery run instead of using the car to get to and from the store.

data.text: As you can see nobody gave you a straight answer. So here it is. First remember that 1 L is equal to 61 cu inches. For example that would be 4inches x 4inches x 4inches of volume. So 1L is quite small volume. The best long distance touring panniers should be waterproof, preferably with compartments so you do not have to dig all over the place to find what you need and minimum of 35L on each side of your rear rack. You can do with 2 30L rear rack panniers and a small 20L-25L duffle bag. One pannier is for cycling clothes and misc cycling stuff. The second pannier is for street clothes, personal stuff etc. The duffel bag on top would be for electronics, cameras, cords, iPhone, iPad, laptop, a book or map and such small but readily accessible things you may need. That will do just fine if you do not plan to do camping out and cooking out. If you are a camping out and cooking out rider you will need some front panniers as well. Not allowed to spell out manufacturer names but I am sure with some basic research you will find what you need. Hope this helps.
